required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Video Game Exercise on Dynamic Balance and Gait in Individuals With Huntington's Disease
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Video Game Biofeedback Modulated Exercise (ViBE)on Dynamic Balance and Gait in Individuals With Huntington's Disease

brief_summary.textblock: To examine the benefits of using a video-game, Dance, Dance, Revolution, as an exercise modality to improve gait and balance in individuals with Huntington's disease.

detailed_description.textblock: The primary purpose of this study was to determine the effectiveness of a therapist-guided Video-game Biofeedback Modulated Exercise (ViBE) program administered via Dance Dance Revolution to improve dynamic balance, gait and mobility in individuals with Huntington's Disease. Secondary aims were to explore whether the ViBE intervention would improve quality of life, fall risk, and neuropsychological functions. The investigators hypothesized that the video-game program would lead to greater improvements in walking, dynamic balance, quality of life, fall risk, and neuropsychological function than a control handheld video game program. Since motivation is essential to the long-term maintenance of an exercise program the investigators were also interested in finding out how successful people with Huntington's Disease were at playing Dance Dance Revolution, what their perceptions were of playing the game, and whether they thought that it was beneficial

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants completed one arm of the study and then crossed over into the other arm of the study

primary_outcome.description: utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: forward velocity.
utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: forward stride length.
utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: forward swing percent.
utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: forward double support percent.
utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: forward heel to heel base of support.
utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: backwards velocity.
utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: backwards stride length.
utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: backwards swing percent.
utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: backwards double support percent.
utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: backwards heel to heel base of support.
utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: obstacle velocity.

secondary_outcome.description: Observation of gait and balance with quantifiable 16-item assessment with an ordinal scale of 0-2 for up to a total score of 32, with higher scores indicating better performance. It is reliable and predicts falls among those with Parkinson's disease and Huntington's disease.

Examines ability to step over an object in multiple directions and is timed. Participants are instructed to step over a cane into each square in a specific order. Faster times indicate better balance. It has been shown to predict falls in the elderly.

Individuals rate their balance confidence from 1-100 on 16 tasks and total score is the mean; higher scores indicate greater confidence and lower fall risk. The Activities-Specific Balance Confidence Scale is reliable and valid in elderly and neurological populations.

secondary_outcome.measure: World Health Organization Quality of Life
secondary_outcome.time_frame: post intervention and post hand-held game, each lasts 6 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: This questionnaire is a measure of quality of life addressing 4 domains including physical, psychological, social, and environment health. Responses on 26 items are on a five-point scale (from 1 = very dissatisfied to 5 = very satisfied) and each item is added to achieve a total score for each domain. The mean score for each domain is calculated then multiplied by 4 to get the domain score which are then transformed to a scaled score of 0-100 comparable to the original WHOQOL-100 therefore a total score between 0-400 with high scores indicating better quality of life. The WHOQOLBref has good reliability and validity.

arm_group.description: Video game exercise using Dance Dance Revolution

intervention.intervention_name: Video game exercise using Dance Dance Revolution
intervention.description: use of the video-game, Dance, Dance Revolution as an exercise to improve gait and balance

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- adults 18 - 79 with a diagnosis of Huntington's disease
Exclusion Criteria:
- cannot walk 10 feet without assistance, any other neurologic condition

facility.name: The Ohio State University Atwell Hall

responsible_party.investigator_title: Associate Professor Clinical Health and Rehabilitation Sciences

group.title: Dance Dance Revolution Exercise, Then Hand Held Video Game (Control)
group.description: Participants first completed the video game exercise using Dance Dance Revolution: use of the video-game, Dance, Dance Revolution as an exercise to improve gait and balance. Then participated in a hand held video game as the control activity.

group.title: Hand Held Video Game (Control), Then Dance Dance Revolution Exercise
group.description: Individuals first participated in the control group: a hand-held video game. Then completed the video game exercise using Dance Dance Revolution: use of the video-game, Dance, Dance Revolution as an exercise to improve gait and balance.

participants_list.participants: N=1 lost to cross over before DDR intervention

group.title: Dance Dance Revolution Exercise, Then Hand Held Video Game (Control)
group.description: Participants first completed the video game exercise using Dance Dance Revolution: use of the video-game, Dance, Dance Revolution as an exercise to improve gait and balance. Then participated in a hand held video game as the control activity.

group.title: Hand Held Video Game (Control), Then Dance Dance Revolution Exercise
group.description: Individuals first participated in the control group: a hand-held video game. Then completed the video game exercise using Dance Dance Revolution: use of the video-game, Dance, Dance Revolution as an exercise to improve gait and balance.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Gait Parameters
outcome.description: utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: forward velocity.
outcome.population: GAITRite outcome data was eliminated for one participant who consistently exhibited an abnormal gait during testing sessions on the walkway that did not reflect his usual walking pattern. One participant could not walk backward. Thus, 17 participants were included in the GAITRite analysis (n = 16 for backward condition).

group.title: Dance Dance Revolution Exercise
group.description: All participants who completed the video game exercise using Dance Dance Revolution either in the first 6 weeks of the study or the second 6 weeks.

group.title: Hand Held Video Game (Control)
group.description: All participants that completed the hand-held video game control group for the first 6 weeks or the second 6 weeks of the study.

measure.description: utilized GAITRite to obtain spatiotemporal measures of gait: forward velocity.
measure.population: GAITRite outcome data was eliminated for one participant who consistently exhibited an abnormal gait during testing sessions on the walkway that did not reflect his usual walking pattern. One participant could not walk backward. Thus, 17 participants were included in the GAITRite analysis (n = 16 for backward condition).

outcome.description: Observation of gait and balance with quantifiable 16-item assessment with an ordinal scale of 0-2 for up to a total score of 32, with higher scores indicating better performance. It is reliable and predicts falls among those with Parkinson's disease and Huntington's disease.

outcome.title: Four Square Step Test
outcome.description: Examines ability to step over an object in multiple directions and is timed. Participants are instructed to step over a cane into each square in a specific order. Faster times indicate better balance. It has been shown to predict falls in the elderly.
outcome.population: Loss of one participant in Four-Square Step Test due to incomplete data

measure.description: Examines ability to step over an object in multiple directions and is timed. Participants are instructed to step over a cane into each square in a specific order. Faster times indicate better balance. It has been shown to predict falls in the elderly.

outcome.title: Activities-Specific Balance Confidence Scale
outcome.description: Individuals rate their balance confidence from 1-100 on 16 tasks and total score is the mean; higher scores indicate greater confidence and lower fall risk. The Activities-Specific Balance Confidence Scale is reliable and valid in elderly and neurological populations.

group.description: All participants who completed the video game exercise using Dance Dance Revolution either in the first 6 weeks of the study or the second 6 weeks.

measure.title: Activities-Specific Balance Confidence Scale
measure.description: Individuals rate their balance confidence from 1-100 on 16 tasks and total score is the mean; higher scores indicate greater confidence and lower fall risk. The Activities-Specific Balance Confidence Scale is reliable and valid in elderly and neurological populations.

outcome.title: World Health Organization Quality of Life
outcome.description: This questionnaire is a measure of quality of life addressing 4 domains including physical, psychological, social, and environment health. Responses on 26 items are on a five-point scale (from 1 = very dissatisfied to 5 = very satisfied) and each item is added to achieve a total score for each domain. The mean score for each domain is calculated then multiplied by 4 to get the domain score which are then transformed to a scaled score of 0-100 comparable to the original WHOQOL-100 therefore a total score between 0-400 with high scores indicating better quality of life. The WHOQOLBref has good reliability and validity.
outcome.time_frame: post intervention and post hand-held game, each lasts 6 weeks
outcome.population: Loss of one participant for the WHOQOL-Bref due to incomplete data

group.title: Video Game Exercise
group.description: Video game exercise using Dance Dance Revolution Video game exercise using Dance Dance Revolution: use of the video-game, Dance, Dance Revolution as an exercise to improve gait and balance

group.description: hand-held video game control hand-held video game: hand-held video games

measure.title: World Health Organization Quality of Life
measure.description: This questionnaire is a measure of quality of life addressing 4 domains including physical, psychological, social, and environment health. Responses on 26 items are on a five-point scale (from 1 = very dissatisfied to 5 = very satisfied) and each item is added to achieve a total score for each domain. The mean score for each domain is calculated then multiplied by 4 to get the domain score which are then transformed to a scaled score of 0-100 comparable to the original WHOQOL-100 therefore a total score between 0-400 with high scores indicating better quality of life. The WHOQOLBref has good reliability and validity.
measure.population: Loss of one participant for the WHOQOL-Bref due to incomplete data

reported_events.time_frame: Course of the time from when the participant was enrolled in the study (8-12 weeks)

group.title: Dance Dance Revolution Exercise
group.description: All participants who were initially enrolled into the group with the video game exercise using Dance Dance Revolution either in the first 6 weeks of the study or the second 6 weeks.

group.title: Hand Held Video Game (Control)
group.description: All participants that who were initially enrolled into the control group with the hand-held video game control for the first 6 weeks or the second 6 weeks of the study.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
